Description: Limestone figure of a uraeus as a stylised cobra resting on top of a tree-trunk. The snake figure has a distinctive raised hood, with a wide snout and ridges indicating the eyes and slit of the mouth. The figure is supported by the raised of a tree trunk on the reverse, which extends to almost the same height as the cobra. The lower body and tail of the cobra is entwined around the base of the tree. There are small abrasions to the stone surface, most notably across the centre of the raised hood and a visible crack along the neck of the cobra. The figure has been attached to a modern rectangular base.
Curator's comments: The label provided on the modern base indicates that the object originates from Benha. The uraeus, as a key symbol of sovereignty, is typically found in royal regalia as an ornament worn upon the king’s forehead, with the hood raised.
